content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice game, it took me quite a while to find an optimized solution. The tests are progressive and well designed. Thanks!
Good game
I'm at 67% of test passed, I hope I‚Äôll be able to submit it in time for approval

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great solo game, had fun solving.
Lots of work on the graphics, rules are simple to understand, more complicated to implement.
Lots of tests/validators that seem to cover everything.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I solved this game with and without backtracking. In both cases, the test case progression led me perfectly down a path to success. The problem description is well written. The graphics are great. I said it before and I'll say it again, I rank this puzzle right near the top of my favorite puzzles on all of CodinGame!

I will make one suggestion. 5 seconds is a lot of time. I think this game would be fine with a 2 second time limit.

This game has become one of my favorite exact cover puzzles of all time. It seems like the game would fit the normal CodinGame input/output model better than the solo game format, but then we would lose the graphics. It took me a while to be comfortable with this, but I got over it. The graphics make these games so much more engaging than traditional puzzles and I am now 100% supportive of the game model, even for this type of input/output puzzle. 

I initially built my logical, problem space reduction step by step. I was thrilled with the test case design. I was only able to pass one more test case each time I submitted new code and the test cases perfectly led me to the next idea. I made it a long way with logic, but then I got stuck. I still have a more ideas for a completely logic-based solution, but I opted to add backtracking.

This puzzle touches on just about every Algorithm X topic in my playground. Again the test cases perfectly guided me as I built out my AlgorithmX subclass and added functionality for multiplicity and row/column checking.

A little debugging quickly brought my logic approach together with my backtracking and here we are. Another outstanding solo game! Great job @VizGhar!

I have no suggestions for any of the associated text. This game appears well-scrubbed and ready to go! As for difficulty level, I found it quite a bit harder than several of your other puzzles. A case could be made for the hard end of medium, but I would lean toward hard. My overall experience with the game was most similar to my experience with There is No Spoon - Episode 2.
What do you guys think of difficulty level? For me it was harder to find solution than in case of my other medium games (maybe except polyominoes, those should be deffinitely in HARD category)
Perfect game! Ready to go!

Rules
* Please add a non-ASCII image (in the same style shown in the viewer) here and explain the possible types of ships.

  - A single-cell ship consists of only one cell.
  
  - All ships of size 2 or longer have a bow cell and a stern cell, with any middle segments filling the space between.

Strategy tips
* Copying all the tips word for word from a website isn't recommended. It may be best to remove this section entirely.

* If you want, you can add "Tips may be found here" next to the website link quoted under "Additional Info".

Game Input
* Line 2: Please change "above" to "for".

* Line 3: Please change "next to" to "for".

Constraints
* 1st constraint: Please change 10 to 15 if the finalised cases will allow 15 as the maximum size.

* 2nd constraint: Please change 15 to "<var>size</var>".

* 4th constraint: Please change 14 to "<var>size</var>".

Logo in the viewer
* The word "Battleship" can sit slightly higher so that it isn't blocked by the battleship graphic.

Cases, viewer and console messages
* I'll check them later.

Thanks.

Wow, those big grids are really big! I'm excited to give this a try. I'll put it on my to-do list for next week.

As you mention in the strategy tips, there are a lot of ways to use logic to reduce the problem. Have you considered some sort of "logic" tag? I'm interested to find out how many test cases can be solved logically without backtracking.

Hi,

Another great solo game, currently solving it, I have an issue with 'Senior Chief Petty Officer', why is this not the solution:
oxxxxoxo
xxooxxxx
xxxxxooo
xxxoxxxx
xoxoxxxx
xoxxxxxx
xoxoxooo
xoxoxxxx
Game is now complete (functionally). I'll work on my own solution now.

> "Game works for first 14 testcases now."
Senior Chief Petty Officer is 15th :) I can prepare rest of the testcases today. I wanted to discuss game mechanics primarily.

But feel free to give me solution for remaining testcases. Less work for me at least
TY. Fixed. Referee is also ready.

I am only through the first 5 test cases and the test case progression is outstanding. I'm not doing any Algorithm X yet. The logical, problem-space reduction has more moving parts than your other games, so it feels harder. I thought Pips was on the easy end of medium. So far, I would put this one on the hard end of medium (more similar difficulty to The Virus), but that could shift to full-out hard as I get into the bigger test cases. I'll keep you posted.
Nicely said. I believe difficulty is same as "There is No Spoon 2" too. It felt like solving exactly same problem... I'l fully retest the referee and change difficulty to hard.
Thank you :)

Constraints
* 2nd constraint: Please change 10 to 6. (Originally I wanted to suggest "min(10, size)" instead, because markers cannot exceed the grid size, but 6 should be sufficient.)

Logo in the viewer
* The word "Battleship" can still sit slightly higher (around 5 pixels).

Referee
* For your info only: the error message "Expecting ${testCase.size} lines representing the solution." seems never to appear.

  ‚Ä¢ When I output too few lines, I only got a Timeout error.

  ‚Ä¢ When I output too many lines, the console still displayed only `testCase.size` output lines. If those were correct, I passed, and the extra lines were ignored.

* No winning message is shown in the console after passing a case.

* Could coordinates be added as an optional feature, displayed when hovering over any cell in the viewer? If that's too complicated, you may combine coordinates with error tooltips as a single option.

* Question: Could the error messages shown in the viewer also be displayed in the console? Alternatively, perhaps append "Refer to the error details by hovering over the cells highlighted in red in the viewer" after "Invalid solution :("?

* For the "Seaman" case,

1. I first tried this output:
oo....
....o.
..o.o.
..o.o.
..o..o
o.....

The 4 cells (2x2) at the top left corner all displayed "Diagonal adjacency detected", even though that isn't the case.

2. I then tried this output:
ooxxxx
xxxxox
xxoxox
xxoxox
xxoxxo
oxxxxx

I output o / x where it was x / o in the original grid. The error messages for those two cells were correct. But visually, they looked the same (circle in a square), which feels a bit confusing.

Shouldn't the final grid in the viewer reflect exactly what the player outputs? If the viewer also needs to indicate the original o's and x's, maybe they should be visually distinguished. If that's too complicated, just showing the player's output supplemented with error messages should be sufficient.

* For the "Surround-whole-boat" case,

1. I tried this output:
xxxxxx
xoooxx
xxxxxx
xxxxxx
xxxxxx
xxxxxx

No error messages were shown in the viewer.

2. If I replaced any of the o's in the above output with "x", I got this error: "Conflict with the original testcase: expected </#/>, but found x". In fact, the expected value there is "o".

3. I then tried this output:
xxxxxx
ooooox
xxxxxx
xxxxxx
xxxxxx
xxxxxx

Cells that were actually correct (note) were flagged as incorrect, while incorrect ones weren't flagged.

Note: By "correct", I mean the cells matched the expected output, but they were interpreted as middle segments instead of bows/sterns in the player's output. It's probably more confusing to treat that as incorrect.

It would be clearer to:

  ‚Ä¢ Mark the genuinely incorrect cells as incorrect, and
  
  ‚Ä¢ Introduce a new error message indicating that those ship cells are touching bow/stern cells from the original grid.

Thanks.

Fixed most of the issues...

- I'd like to see both initial configuration and player's solution (I'll probably add some kind of "minimap" of initial configuration, but it's too much work).

- Also I'm not sure whether I can highlight missing/rendundand ships, thats why you can only see red frame around fleet display at bottom-left. (reaction to your "Surround-whole-boat" issue 1)

for example in case of
xox
ooo
there can be at least 5 different boat configurations possible (all incorrect)

Understood your concerns. I'll answer them in the last point below.

Console messages
* You can remove the sentence "Refer to the error details by hovering over the cells highlighted in red in the viewer.", since all error messages are now displayed in the console. That sentence is only needed when the console doesn't show the errors.

* "Expected 1 ship cells in row 2, got 2": Please either change "cells" to "cell(s)", or change the word to singular when the number is 1.

* "Incorrect combination of ships used.": For clarity, please replace the message with: The number and size of ships used does not match the expected fleet.

Viewer
* Debug options: Please change "COORDINATIONS" to "COORDINATES". (Hopefully that'll also resolve the issue of the label being too long and getting cut off?)

* Noted that you'd like to see both the initial configuration and player's solution, and you aren't sure how to highlight missing or redundant ships (and also sea, for that matter). Here is my suggestion:

  ‚Ä¢ The representations differs depending on whether the player's solution is completely correct or not.
  
  ‚Ä¢ When the player's solution is not 100% correct, each cell is drawn in 4 layers (from bottom to top):

    1. Grey background (instead of white)
    
    2. Wavy line pattern (dashed and/or solid) filling the entire cell to represent the sea
    
    3. Hollow circle (dashed or solid outline) to represent a ship, regardless of whether it's a middle segment or not
    
    4. Red overlay to mark an error
    
  ‚Ä¢ The solid wavy line pattern shouldn't be too dense, to avoid visual overload. It should look something like this:
ÔπèÔπè
ÔπèÔπè
ÔπèÔπè

  ‚Ä¢ Dashed elements indicate information from the initial configuration.
  
  ‚Ä¢ Solid elements indicate information from the player's configuration.
  
  ‚Ä¢ Superimposed solid on dashed of the same element (circle on circle, waves on waves) = agreement between the initial and the player's configurations.
  
  ‚Ä¢ Dashed circle on dashed waves or vice versa = inconsistency with the initial configuration.
  
  ‚Ä¢ A red overlay is then applied to every cell where the player's configuration doesn't match the expected configuration.
  
  ‚Ä¢ When the player's solution is completely correct, the display can switch back to the existing style: use solid (filled) circles and partially rounded squares to represent the ships.

Thanks.

Dashed lines definitely helped. Thanks

Still need to soften the visual but now it looks much better.

- water cell needs either less waves or softer color
- error highlights should be more transparent
- do you like placed ship cells being smaller than dashed outline?

Yay, the updated visuals look great!

* I really like the transition from the output state to the final correct state. It feels like the battleships are being exposed as we correctly identify their positions.

* The sea cells look good as they are, so I don't think adjustments are necessary. That said, I'm open to seeing your tweaks in case they improve things further.

* I agree that the error highlights should be made a bit more transparent.

* The placed ship cells being smaller than the dashed outlines looks fine to me, especially on larger grids where everything scales down.

* In the initial configuration, "<" and ">" are shown as "‚óó" and "‚óñ" in the viewer, so they appear flipped in the wrong directions. Refer to Frame 0 of "Surround-whole-boat" for an example. For comparison, "^" and "v" are represented correctly.
OK, I believe now it's a little bit better :) I'll try to implement my own solution and push it to READY state

Referee
* At the moment, the referee flags an error when an output ship cell touches the bow/stern of another ship. However, it doesn't flag an error when an output ship cell touches a single-cell ship. Will such detection be added?

Viewer
* The initial configuration is currently displayed in green, which feels inconsistent with the battleship or ocean theme. Could the colouring be adjusted to be more blue than green?

Thanks.

Added Referee check you mentioned.
Updated viewer as well - updated colors, replaced water assets and numbers on side. Now it looks even better.

Got my own solution working as well, so it's probably ready to go

Thank you. I'll review the contribution again later.

Have you done further testing? I'm worried that I might still miss something ü§î

Good job; the graphics look much prettier now! I think it would be better to switch back to solid lines instead of dashed ones for the initial configuration, since the current colours already make them distinctive. An initially configured solid-line sea/ship icon would also be clearer when overlaid with a player's ship/sea, especially on large grids where icons are small (the current dashed version looks a bit unclear). Alternatively, you could consider using denser dashed lines.

In addition, as suggested by Timinator, consider upgrading the difficulty level of the puzzle to Hard.

Hope you've done more testing in general!

Thanks.
I still need to fully test it. It'll stay in WIP until then. Huge thanks for your inputs.

Retested the game found only one issue. Input is handled properly (size x size characters and only x/o accepted) but:

In case of single cell ship only one bow/stern touch rule breach was highlighted even if it was fully surrounded. I've also tried to pass the test with breaking only single rule. So I believe game is ready to go.

I also applied recommended visual changes.
The graphic is pretty and clear now. Thanks.

What do you mean by "to receive some rules to pick from each turn"?
You can solve the game in a single turn and then for example return the positions of the ships one position per turn, I assume that would make the animation smoother but I don't know how much more complicated it would be for you in the background. The order wouldn't matter because you could check if each new boat part violates any of the rules.

I meant something different, but it doesn't matter. The player should focus on solving puzzle. I'll just make it single turn solo game. I'll prepare the referee in a few hours.

Hmm hardcoded solutions won't work, because I need to visualize errors. I've implemented referee (not tested properly yet). Can you try your solution now? I don't have my own ready... This puzzle is taking me much more time than expected

I pass every tests/validators expect 'Rear Admiral Lower Half (Validator)'
The hint row 0 must be at least 3 based on inputs but it's currently 0.
